content: Thunderbird 60 is ancient and has had no updates for years. Fundamentally you are on your own, but I would suggest you look at what has changed in the operating system. You might get something from changing the setting for hardware acceleration as historically changing the video drive could change the setting required in Thunderbird.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
>>Thunderbird 60 is ancient and has had no updates for years.

Thank you for pointing this out. I thought I was on a current version. If the regular update process won't get me there, I will try a reinstall and report back.
creator: gentle_friend

content:
Do not install the most current version straight off. You should install intermediate versions because they contain migration steps for your data.

  • Install version 68, and start up.
  • Install version 78, and start up.
  • From there Help > About should step you through the updates.
creator: wsmwk

content: Is it enough to run these installers on top of the current version or is there a special procedure? (I'm searching but not finding anything)
creator: gentle_friend

content:
Yes, on top. In fact that is critical, because if you install it in a different program folder then Thunderbird will want you to create a new data profile.

Note, make a backup of your data profile before each step https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile
creator: wsmwk

content:
I was actually able to get the application to update itself to 68.12.1, at which point the modal disappeared. Then four or five more updates brought it to the current version (no installation files needed).

Matt and Wayne -- thanks for your help!

If you are talking about threading, you can turn it off. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/message-threading-thunderbird

Otherwise you can sort emails any way you like by clicking the heading on the list, once to sort, the next to sort the reverse order.

Or use the icon (top right corner) in the image below to use the menu for sorting.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I have answered lots of these question and no one has got back to me, so I am guess that most of these questions are from folk that have sub folders on their inbox and do not realize that when those are collapsed in the folder view unread mail in them is included in the visible folder count. Such as the two views on the trash folder below.

Other than that other common issues are;

Do you have the quick filter bar active and limiting display to unread mail only? Do you have the folders showing only unread emails

Then there is most email accounts these days are IMAP and they are syncronised to the server, so if you delete a message, move it or mark it as read on one device, all will see it that way.

content:
onix said
I would like to have either of these options:
  1. Numbered list item Set Get All Messages to Download/Sync now...
  2. Numbered list item A (custom) button on the Toolbar for Download/Sync now...

Like this?

Right click the toolbar and select customize to add the things that are not on the toolbar by default. There are lots of them.

There is also always the keyboard.

While there was a suggestion in this [https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/que.../1387615|thread] to add the following into the Config Editor. It does not work.
  • Bulleted list item 'mail.server.default.check_all_folders_for_new' set as 'TRUE'

That simply tells Thunderbird to synchronise all folders for an IMAP account when it is checking mail. There is a bug that illustrates some of the issues and why it is not enabled by default here https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1659311#c27

content:
onix said
There is definitely no such option.

Utter rubbish. What I posted was taken today from my installation of Thunderbird 115. So of course the option and the icon exist. If you are unable to find it that is another issue. Keyboard shortcut is three layers deep, with ALT + SHIFT + f, plus unreliable other clicks thereafter. That is not what I'm seeking unfortunately.

I showed you the menu, but you do not need it to use shortcuts That is why they are called shortcuts. Press F1 anywhere in Thunderbird and you will be taken to this forum, because there is an entry on the help menu. with that shortcut defined. Likewise press Shift+F5 to get all messages from all accounts or just F5 to get message for the current account, like it shows on the menu.

content:
trisweb said
I apologize in advance, as I am a UX designer and have thought quite a bit about this and have a very clear idea of how it works today, and how it ought to work, and a very confident opinion about several of the workarounds and steps to make it work in the simple logical way it ought to.

In your opinion. Perhaps before you go on you might want to look at the UX discussions, or even contribute. https://thunderbird.topicbox.com/groups/ux

So I will be direct, and I don't really need help or assistance with workarounds or extensions, this is going to be a well-defined post about what Thunderbird needs to do differently to achieve a significantly clearer experience.

Thunderbird has a link on the help menu for feedback and ideas. It goes to this site https://connect.mozilla.org If you want anyone but other users to see your idea, I suggest you post them where the application hosts it's feedback and ideas forum or in a User experience list such as the one I linked to earlier.

content: If you're sending through the gmail smtp from a non-gmail account, gmail will automatically switch the sending account with the gmail address, so recipients see the message as being sent from the gmail address. Open gmail settings on gmail.com, and in the Accounts & Import section, Send mail as, add the non-gmail account.

content: Instead of adding your domain account as a sender in gmail, you should add an smtp server to TB with your domain settings, e.g. it might be something like: smtp.yourdomain.com, 465, SSL/TLS, normal password, email address. content:
Outgoing server (SMTP) error. The server responded: * OK The Microsoft Exchange IMAP4 service is ready.

Outgoing server error is that the incoming server is ready. But default that sounds very odd to me.

Go to the outgoing server (SMTP) entry in Thunderbird account settings and find the outgoing server that has IMAP in the server name That is where to problem must be, either an incorrect outgoing server setting or an incorrect port number which us getting the server thinking you are getting mail not sending it. Of one thing I am certain. You setting are the most likely cause of this Could you also please do the following?

  1. Open the menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information, then click Copy text to Clipboard.
  2. Go to https://pastebin.mozilla.org/, paste the clipboard by right clicking in the large text area, select paste from the menu, change the retention period to expire in 28 days, use the Paste Snippet button to create a page containing your info, then copy the resulting URL (address) of the page created.
  3. Open a reply to this post, and paste the URL to your troubleshooting information you just copied.

That way we might be able to get some insight into where the settings are actually wrong.

content:
In your Account Settings change the Authentication method for the incoming server to "OAuth2". In Settings/Privacy & Security, remove the entries from Saved Passwords. Cookies must be allowed in Thunderbird for OAuth2 to work. Restart TB, and enter the account password in the OAuth2 window when prompted.

If you're still having problems after that please post your Troubleshooting Information. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡, then select Help > More Troubleshooting Information. Press the "Copy text to clipboard button" and paste the information into your reply.

Also explain in detail:

  • what you're doing,
  • what happens,
  • what you expect to happen.

content:
Of course they are cumbersome, because they are not intended to be used except in exceedingly rare circumstances. The present a number of basically Linux only setting or very advanced setting that should never really be edited.

If you are not getting links to work. Start by checking your operating system has a default browser set. Then go and have a look in settings at the helper applications. If there is anything there about HTML or HTM documents delete it.

If it is not fixed at that point, uninstall your antivirus and see if things get better. (BTW it is usually the antivirus, some addon it injected into Thunderbird or it's firewall component that is the issue, not Thunderbird.) When folk work out it is not a Thunderbird issue at all the quietly say no more and we never hear from them again. If they spend time fixing the antivirus or just remove it. I really don't know.

content:
Gmail pop server says something is wrong with your server settings. In Account Settings > Server Settings for the gmail account.

Right hand side should say:

  • Server Type: POP mail server
  • Server name : pop.gmail.com
  • Port: 995
  • User name: full gmail email address of account
  • Connection Securiyt: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication method: OAuth2

Please check all the above is correct.

content: Is the scan app 32 or 64-bit? Is TB 32 or 64-bit? TB is probably 64-bit, but if the scan app is 32-bit, TB must also be 32-bit for them to connect.
creator: sfhowes

content:
You mention Google and several computers accessing same account. So I'm assuming you are using an imap mail accounts on all computers and that would also include any access to account via a phone.

Logon to the gmail webmail account via a browser, do you see the emails on the server? If yes: In Thunderbird

  • Right click on folder which is contiains the missing emails and select 'Properties'
  • Click on 'Repair' folder
  • click on 'OK'

re : search for the missing messages, they show up in the the search results

But can you open any of the searched results to see email - I'm assuming no.

Check to see if there are any filters operating which may alter what you see. Select folder that should contain emails. Check the following is selected:

  • View > Folders > All
  • View > Threads > All

Are any of the icons enabled in the 'Quick Filter Bar'? If yes:

  • click on the enabled icon to deselect.

Check to see if the imap account folder needs to set up as subscribed again.

  • Right click on gmail mail account name in Folder Pane and select 'Subscribe'
  • click on 'Refresh' button
  • select folder and click on 'Subscribe'
  • click on 'OK'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Uninstalling/reinstalling TB seldom fixes problems with the (separate) profile folder. But testing with a new profile might help: Help/Troubleshooting Info, about:profiles.

Windows 10 & 11 have a built-in mail app now called Outlook, that includes mail, calendar and contacts.

Maybe your PC has an external app like antivirus that's different from your wife's. As mentioned above, run Windows in safe mode to test the effect of startup apps like AV that are bypassed in safe mode. AVG/Avast are common causes of sending errors.
